{{Infobox oil spill | spill_name = 2007 South Korean oil spill | image = Daesanport.png | image_size = | image_caption =Map of Daesan port, [[South Korea]] | location = Daesan port, [[South Korea]] | coordinates = | spill_date = {{start date and age|2007|12|07}} | cause = Collision of crane barge with MT ''Hebei Spirit'' | operator = | volume = <!--{{convert|10.8|e6USgal|oilbbl m3|abbr=on|lk=in}}--> | area = {{convert|330000|m2|abbr=on}} | coast = {{convert|33|km|abbr=on}} }}
[[File:Manripo071210 8.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A volunteer worker collects oil from the beach]] [[File:Manripo071210 9.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Police officers volunteering]] The '''MT ''Hebei Spirit'' oil spill''' was a major [[oil spill]] in [[South Korea]] that began on the morning of 7 December 2007 local time, with ongoing environmental and economic effects. Government officials called it South Korea's worst oil spill ever, surpassing a spill that took place in 1995.<ref name="Worst Oil Spill">{{cite news | url = https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2007/12/202_15206.html| title = Worst Oil Spill| publisher = ''[[Korea Times]]''| date = 2007-12-09|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110520091038/https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2007/12/202_15206.html |archivedate = 20 May 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="Channel Newws Asia">{{cite news | url = http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/316137/1/.html | title = South Korea battles worst oil spill ever: officials| publisher = [[Channel News Asia]]| date = 2007-12-08}}</ref> This oil spill was about one-third of the size of the [[Exxon Valdez oil spill|''Exxon Valdez'' oil spill]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7135896.stm | work=BBC News | title=South Korea fights huge oil spill | date=2007-12-10 | accessdate=2010-04-22}}</ref>
==Background== At about 7:30 local time on 7 December 2007 (2230 UTC on 6 December 2007), a [[Crane vessel|crane barge]] owned by [[Samsung Heavy Industries]] being towed by a tug collided with the anchored [[Hong Kong]] registered [[Petroleum tanker#Merchant tankers|crude carrier]] ''Hebei Spirit'' ({{zh|c=河北精神號}}), carrying {{convert|260000|t|ST|lk=on}} of crude oil. The incident occurred near the port of Daesan on the [[Yellow Sea]] coast of [[Taean]] County. The barge was floating free after the cable linking it to the tug snapped in the rough seas.
Although no casualties were reported, the collision punctured three of the five tanks aboard the ''Hebei Spirit'' and resulted in the leaking of some {{convert|10800|t|ST}} of oil.<ref name="Al Jazeera - 07/12">{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/8FFD07BA-FC96-4272-A88F-016EB6BFD8C2.htm |title=Tanker oil spill off S Korea coast |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=2007-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209183511/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/8FFD07BA-FC96-4272-A88F-016EB6BFD8C2.htm |archivedate=2007-12-09 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Al Jazeera - 09/12">{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/4B8CD7E8-4A7E-4723-AEB2-1FD8A8CDCE51.htm |title=S Korea fights worst oil spill ever |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=2007-12-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071210063213/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/4B8CD7E8-4A7E-4723-AEB2-1FD8A8CDCE51.htm |archivedate=2007-12-10 |df= }}</ref> The remaining oil from the damaged tanks was pumped into the undamaged tanks and the holes were sealed.<ref name="AFP">{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jmxiCRp0tXcdprM3rl4eVTzRDRnw |title=SKorea oil spill fight to last months: minister |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] |date=2007-12-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071213174919/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jmxiCRp0tXcdprM3rl4eVTzRDRnw |archivedate=2007-12-13 |df= }}</ref><ref name="BBC World">{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7134967.stm| title = S Korea declares slick 'disaster'| publisher = [[BBC World]]| date = 2007-12-09}}</ref>
The spill occurred near Mallipo Beach (in Taean County), considered one of South Korea's most beautiful and popular beaches.<ref name="CNN">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/12/09/skorea.spill.ap/index.html |title=South Korea faces 'sea of oil' |publisher=[[CNN International]] |date=2007-12-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071210074523/http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/12/09/skorea.spill.ap/index.html |archivedate=December 10, 2007 }}</ref> The region affected by the spill is home to one of Asia's largest wetland areas, used by migratory birds, and also contains a national maritime park and 445 sea farms.<ref name="Al Jazeera - 09/12"/>
==Effects== It was initially believed the oil spill would not spread due to the cold winter temperatures. However, unseasonably warm weather, combined with strong waves and unexpected wind directions, caused the spill to expand beyond initial expectations.<ref name="Korean Times-09/12">{{cite news | url = https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2007/12/113_15224.html | title = Clearing Oil Contamination to Take at Least Two Months| publisher = [[Korea Times]]| date = 2007-12-09}}</ref>
On 9 December it was reported that the oil slick was already {{convert|33|km|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|10|m|abbr=on}} wide and {{convert|10|cm|abbr=on|0}} thick in some areas.<ref name="Al Jazeera - 09/12"/><ref name="BBC World"/><ref name="Korean Times-09/12"/> It was also reported that at least 30 beaches have been affected and over half of the region's sea farms are believed to have lost their stocks due to the spill. [[DuWoong wetland|Sinduri Dune]], a [[National Treasures of South Korea|South Korean natural treasure]],<!-- Please don't change this to national treasure, our current ref calls it a natural treasure so until a better ref is found we should follow the ref--> is reported to have been saturated by the spill.<ref name="Korean Times-09/12"/>
Although most [[migratory bird]]s had not yet arrived in the region, [[seagull]]s, [[mallard duck]]s and other sea life were found tarred by the oil.<ref name="CNN"/><ref name="Korean Times-09/12"/>
On 14 December, the oil balls had arrived at Anmyeon-do<ref>http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_1_1_1.jsp?cid=264575</ref> (安眠島; Anmyeon Island), resulting in at least five beaches being contaminated with large tar lumps. It was believed that the oil belt was not going to go down to Anmyeon-do, but bad, windy weather was responsible for it. On 15 December, the tar lumps had also floated to [[Boryeong]] (mostly around Wonsan Island<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maplandia.com/korea-south/chungchongnam-do/wonsando-ri/|title=Wonsando-ri Map - South Korea Google Satellite Maps|first=Maplandia.com|last=Team|website=www.maplandia.com}}</ref> and Sapsi Island of Boryeong) and to [[Gunsan]] in [[North Jeolla]] province as well.<!--<ref name="Yonhap News"/>-->
==Response== The South Korean government declared a state of disaster in the region. The cost of cleanup has been estimated at 300 billion [[South Korean won]] (US$330 million). The cleanup involved 13 helicopters, 17 airplanes and 327 vessels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/dec2007/2007-12-31-02.asp|title=Rehab Prospects Good After Korea's Worst Oil Spill|first=|last=staff|website=www.ens-newswire.com}}</ref> It has also been estimated the cleanup will take at least two months.<ref name="Worst Oil Spill"/><ref name="Korean Times-09/12"/> Hundreds of thousands of volunteers and celebrities including South Korean actress [[Park Jin-hee]] helped to clean up the beaches in the campaign.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} As of 4 January 2008, the Navy had deployed 229 vessels and some 22,000 military personnel to help clean up the spill, in addition to civilian aid.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://korea.net/News/News/NewsView.asp?serial_no=20080104005 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-01-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170101201253/http://korea.net/News/News/NewsView.asp?serial_no=20080104005 |archivedate=2017-01-01 |df= }} </ref>
On 10 January 2008, the number of volunteers topped the 1-million mark to reach 1,037,000 people, 33 days after the accident occurred on 7 December, according to the South Chungcheong provincial government.<ref name="kois1">{{cite web|url=http://www.kois.go.kr/News/News/NewsView.asp?serial_no%3D20080111033 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516130658/http://www.kois.go.kr/News/News/NewsView.asp?serial_no=20080111033 |archivedate=2011-05-16 |df= }}</ref> The Taean office for emergency operations reported that the volunteers included 580,000 ordinary civilians, 186,700 local residents, 127,000 soldiers and policemen, and 57,143 public officials. According to the emergency office, an average of 20,000 people volunteered during weekdays and 3,000 volunteered over the weekends.<ref name="koreatimes1">{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/01/117_17071.html |title=Number of Oil Cleanup Volunteers Top 1 Mil. |accessdate=April 4, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224221028/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/01/117_17071.html |archivedate=February 24, 2012 }}</ref>
By January 2008, approximately 4,153 tons of crude oil spilled had been collected by utilizing some 268,710 kilograms of oil absorbents and other cleanup devices.<ref name="koreatimes1"/> Financial contributions combined to 27.76 billion [[South Korean won]] (about 20 million euro) in donations, as well as food and clothing. The Taean emergency center said more than seven billion won in donations have come from about 4,200 organizations and individuals.<ref name="kois1"/>
Internationally, the Regional Oil Spill Contingency Plan under the [[Northwest Pacific Action Plan]] (NOWPAP) was activated<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nowpap.org/|title=NOWPAP-Northwest Pacific Action Plan|website=www.nowpap.org}}</ref> following a request of the South Korean government. Among the emergency supplies available in the other three NOWPAP members (China, Japan and Russia), South Korean government, taking into account logistical issues, accepted kind offers of 50 and 10 tonnes of sorbents from China and Japan respectively. Japan has also dispatched a team of experts in addition to the teams from the Joint UNEP/OCHA (UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs<ref>http://ochaonline.un.org/OchaLinkClick.aspx?link=ocha&docId=1084754/</ref>{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}) Environment Unit and the European Commission Monitoring Information Center, [[U.S. Coast Guard]] and the [[Autonomous University of Barcelona]] (AUB).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unep.org/Documents.Multilingual/Default.asp?DocumentID=523&ArticleID=5728&l=en/|title=Press Releases December 2007 – UNEP deploys team of experts to help with oil spill in Republic of Korea – United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP)|publisher=}}</ref>
==Responsibility== [[File:Manripo071210 2.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Volunteers cleaning up]] It has been reported that the regional office of the [[Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries|Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries]] had twice tried to warn the barge captain that the barge was too close to the tanker two hours before the incident but was unable to do so.<ref name="Worst Oil Spill"/> The barge captain is also under investigation for moving through the area in rough weather.<ref name="CNN"/> The tanker is reported to have been at anchor when it was hit by the barge, which had broken free from its towing lines.<ref name="BBC World" />
The South Korean [[Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries|Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries]] and police admitted to having not provided sufficient amount of oil absorbent material to fishermen and residents as well as not having paid enough attention to the wind direction.<ref name="Korean Times-09/12"/>
According to a recent report, compensation will be mostly paid by China Shipowners Mutual Assurance Association (China P&I) and [[Assuranceforeningen Skuld|Skuld P&I]], which are insurers for the ''Hebei Spirit'', and some paid by [[Samsung Fire]] and Lloyd P&I.<ref name="대산항 해양오염 발생현황">{{cite news | url = http://www.newswire.co.kr/read_sub.php?id=303615| script-title=ko:대산항 해양오염 발생현황| publisher = NewsWire| date = 2007-12-09 |language=Korean}}</ref> International Oil Pollution Funds (IOPC) will be responsible to pay if China P&I and Skuld P&I become unable to pay for the cost or if the damages exceed the shipowners limitation of liability set under an international convention.
On 20 December, the South Korean coast guard completed an initial investigation. According to their conclusions, blame is shared between the tug captains, the barge captain, and the captain of the Hebei Spirit. The tug captains and the barge captain are charged with negligence and violating the marine pollution prevention law. The captain of the Hebei Spirit has been charged with violating marine law.<ref>[http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2884189 INSIDE JoongAng Daily] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608030841/http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2884189 |date=June 8, 2011 }}</ref>
On 24 June, the trial concluded. The two tug captains were found guilty, while the personnel on the barge and on Hebei Spirit were exonerated. Samsung Heavy Industries was also fined.<ref>[http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200806/200806240014.html Digital Chosunilbo (English Edition) : Daily News in English About Korea] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626231742/http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200806/200806240014.html |date=June 26, 2008 }}</ref>
==Controversy over continued detention of crew== However, the Hebei Spirit's two most senior officers, Master Jasprit Chawla and chief officer Syam Chetan, continue to be detained in South Korea. They were found guilty of criminal negligence and sentenced to serve time in jail for 18 months (Master Jasprit Chawla) and 8 months (C.O. Syam Chetan). South Korea's detention of the crew has generated much controversy and protests from around the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/News/News_By_Industry/Transportation/Shipping__Transport/Protests_against_piracy_detention_of_seamen/articleshow/3588048.cms|title=Protests against piracy, detention of seamen|date=13 October 2008|publisher=|via=The Economic Times}}</ref><ref>[http://www.expressbuzz.com/edition/story.aspx?artid=/HM/o8XRBJI=&Title=Mariners+hold+silent+march+in+the+City&SectionID=lifojHIWDUU=&MainSectionID=ngGbWGz5Z14=&SectionName=rSY|6QYp3kQ=&SEO=SOUTH,KOREA,CAPTAIN,MARINERS,RELEASE India Express: Mariners hold silent march in the City, Expressbuzz.com, 6 Oct 2008] {{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref> There have been strong protests from the shipping world and demands for the crews release, including from organizations like the International Transport Workers’ Federation, International Group of P&I Clubs, BIMCO, International Chamber of Shipping / International Shipping Federation, [[International Association of Dry Cargo Shipowners]] (INTERCARGO), International Association of Independent Tanker Owners (INTERTANKO) and the Hong Kong Shipowners' Association.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marinenorway.etp.no/sider/tekst.asp?side=3405|title=eRedaktør publiseringsløsning|first=|last=eredaktor|website=marinenorway.etp.no}}</ref>
==Claims of Samsung, prosecutors collusion in appeal case== According to Lloyd's List and other media reports, South Korean maritime officials, prosecutors and Samsung lawyers have been accused of colluding in the retrial of the two senior officers. Roberto Giorgi, president of management firm V.Ships, visited South Korea to meet with the detained Hebei Spirit crew.<ref>http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/viewArticle.htm?articleId=20017574484 {{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref> He told the press that he is concerned at recent developments "which point to collusion" between the South Korean authorities, prosecutors and Samsung Heavy Industries, operators of a drifting barge that collided with the oil tanker and that efforts of Samsung and prosecutors "look to be designed to ensure that the master and chief officer are found guilty on appeal," Giorgi said. "I am worried that the captain and chief officer may not get a fair trial this time around."<ref>http://www.france24.com/en/20080924-firm-says-it-suspects-collusion-skorea-oil-spill-case {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>

{{multiple image |align = upright |image1 = Air purifier.JPG |caption1 = A Sharp FU-888SV Plasmacluster air purifier. |image2 = Sharp FU-888SV internal 20061020.jpg |caption2 = The same air purifier, cover removed. }} An '''air purifier''' or '''air cleaner''' is a device which removes [[contaminant]]s from the air in a room. These devices are commonly marketed as being beneficial to [[allergy]] sufferers and [[asthma]]tics, and at reducing or eliminating [[passive smoking|second-hand tobacco smoke]]. The commercially graded air purifiers are manufactured as either small stand-alone units or larger units that can be affixed to an air handler unit (AHU) or to an [[HVAC]] unit found in the medical, industrial, and commercial industries. Air purifiers may also be used in industry to remove impurities such as CO<sub>2</sub> from air before processing. [[Pressure swing adsorption|Pressure swing adsorbers]] or other adsorption techniques are typically used for this.
==History== In 1830, a patent was awarded to [[Charles Anthony Deane]] for a device comprising a copper helmet with an attached flexible collar and garment. A long leather hose attached to the rear of the helmet was to be used to supply air, the original concept being that it would be pumped using a double [[bellows]]. A short pipe allowed breathed air to escape. The garment was to be constructed from leather or airtight cloth, secured by straps.<ref>{{cite book | last = Newton | first = William | last2 = Partington | first2 = Charles Frederick | title = Charles Anthony Deane - 1823 patent | journal = Newton's London Journal of Arts and Sciences | volume = 9 | issue = | pages = 341 | year = 1825 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=IwA1AAAAMAAJ | doi = | id = | publisher = W. Newton }}</ref>
In the 1860s, [[John Stenhouse]] filed two patents applying the absorbent properties of [[Charcoal|wood charcoal]] to air purification (patents 19 July 1860 and 21 May 1867), thereby creating the first practical [[respirator]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Stenhouse, John|journal=Dictionary of National Biography|date=1885–1900|volume=54|url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Stenhouse,_John_(DNB00)}}</ref>
A few years later, [[John Tyndall]] invented an improvement to the fireman's respirator, a hood that filtered smoke and noxious gas from air (1871, 1874).<ref>Ian Taggart [http://www33.brinkster.com/iiiii/gasmask/page.html History of air-purifying type gas-masks in the 19th-century] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502145330/http://www33.brinkster.com/iiiii/gasmask/page.html |date=2013-05-02 }}. John Tyndall (1871), [https://archive.org/stream/fragmentsscienc10tyndgoog#page/n318/mode/2up ''Fireman's Respirator''], and {{cite journal|jstor=112853 |author=John Tyndall |title=On Some Recent Experiments with a Fireman's Respirator |doi=10.1098/rspl.1873.0060 |url=https://archive.org/details/philtrans07303711 |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London |volume=22 |year=1874 |pages=359–361 |issue=148–155 }}</ref>
In the 1950s, [[HEPA]] filters were commercialized as highly efficient air filters, after being put to use in the 1940s in the United States' [[Manhattan Project]] to control airborne [[radioactive decay|radioactive]] contaminants.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XtXJzogLCecC&pg=PA13&dq=HEPA+filter+manhattan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiHybWO0P7QAhVJzoMKHTdQBQ0Q6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=HEPA%20filter%20manhattan&f=false|title=Green Health: An A-to-Z Guide|last=Ogunseitan|first=Oladele|date=2011-05-03|publisher=SAGE|isbn=9781412996884|location=|page=13|language=en|via=}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QSNfCrpcSCAC&pg=PA128&dq=HEPA+filter+registered+trademark&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjwtuC80P7QAhWr7IMKHZudCQ0Q6AEIMjAA#v=onepage&q=HEPA%20filter%20registered%20trademark&f=false|title=The Vacuum Cleaner: A History|last=Gantz|first=Carroll|date=2012-09-21|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9780786493210|location=|page=128|language=en|via=}}</ref>
==Use and benefits of purifiers== [[Dust]], [[pollen]], pet [[dander]], [[mold]] [[spore]]s, and [[dust mite]] [[feces]] can act as [[allergens]], triggering [[allergies]] in sensitive people. Smoke [[particulate|particles]] and [[volatile organic compound]]s (VOCs) can pose a risk to health. Exposure to various components such as VOCs increases the likelihood of experiencing symptoms of [[sick building syndrome]].<ref name="ang">H.M. Ang, M Tade, S Wang. (2007). "Volatile organic compounds in the indoor environment and photo-catalytic oxidation: state of the art". Environmental International 33: 694-705.</ref>
==Purifying techniques== [[File:パナ エコナビ ナノイー 空気清浄機 2016 (29772555192).jpg|thumb|An air purifier placed under a table]] There are two types of air purifying technologies, Active and Passive. Active [[air purifier]] use ionisation for cleaning the air. Passive air purification units on the other hand use air filters to remove [[Pollutant|pollutants]]. They are more efficient since all [[dust]] and [[Particulate matter|Particulate Matter]] is permanently removed from the air and collected in the filters.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.honeywellsmarthomes.com/blog/what-kind-of-filters-are-required-for-an-air-purifier-to-work-efficiently/|title=Types and Function of Air Filters {{!}} Air Filtration System For Home, Office and Car|date=2017-09-04|work=Official Blog Updates - Honeywell Air Purifiers|access-date=2018-02-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
Several different processes of varying effectiveness can be used to purify air.
*Thermodynamic sterilization (TSS) - This technology uses heat sterilization via a ceramic core with micro capillaries, which are heated to {{convert|200|°C}}. It is claimed that 99.9% of microbiological particles - bacteria, viruses, dust mite allergens, mold and fungus spores - are incinerated.<ref>{{cite web |title=Insect Research Institute UK |url=http://www.airfree.uk.com/Files/Billeder/AirFree/Testes/Insect%20Research%20Institute%20UK.pdf |website=Airfree |date=15 July 2018}}</ref> The air passes through the ceramic core by the natural process of [[convection|air convection]], and is then cooled using heat transfer plates and released.<ref>{{cite web |title=Most effective air purification method or mechanism |url=http://www.olansi.net/ |website=Olasi Healthcare Co. |date=15 July 2018}}</ref> TSS is not a filtering technology, as it does not trap or remove particles.<ref>http://www.airfree.uk.com/Files/Billeder/AirFree/371106146.pdf</ref> TSS is claimed not to emit harmful by-products (although the byproducts of partial [[pyrolysis|thermal decomposition]] are not addressed) and also reduces the concentration of ozone in the atmosphere.<ref>{{cite web |title=Swedish National Testing and Research Institute Ozone |url=http://www.breathingspace.co.uk/downloads/1409654777SP_Swedish_National_Testing_and_Research_Institute_Ozone.pdf |website=Breathing Space |date=15 July 2018}}</ref> *[[Ultraviolet germicidal irradiation]] - UVGI can be used to sterilize air that passes UV lamps via forced air. Air purification UVGI systems can be freestanding units with shielded UV lamps that use a fan to force air past the UV light. Other systems are installed in forced air systems so that the circulation for the premises moves micro-organisms past the lamps. Key to this form of sterilization is placement of the UV lamps and a good filtration system to remove the dead micro-organisms. For example, forced air systems by design impede line-of-sight, thus creating areas of the environment that will be shaded from the UV light. However, a UV lamp placed at the coils and drainpan of cooling system will keep micro-organisms from forming in these naturally damp places. The most effective method for treating the air rather than the coils is in-line duct systems, these systems are placed in the center of the duct and parallel to the air flow. *[[Air filter|Filter]] - based purification traps airborne particles by size exclusion. Air is forced through a filter and particles are physically captured by the filter. :High-efficiency particulate arrestance ([[HEPA]]) filters remove at least 99.97% of 0.3-micrometer particles and are usually more effective at removing larger particles. HEPA purifiers, which filter all the air going into a [[clean room]], must be arranged so that no air bypasses the HEPA filter. In dusty environments, a HEPA filter may follow an easily cleaned conventional filter (prefilter) which removes coarser impurities so that the HEPA filter needs cleaning or replacing less frequently. HEPA filters do not generate ozone or harmful byproducts in course of operation. :Filter HVAC at [[Minimum Efficiency Reporting Value|MERV]] 14 or above are rated to remove airborne particles of 0.3 micrometers or larger. A high efficiency MERV 14 filter has a capture rate of at least 75% for particles between 0.3 to 1.0 micrometers. Although the capture rate of a MERV filter is lower than that of a HEPA filter, a central air system can move significantly more air in the same period of time. Using a high-grade MERV filter can be more effective than using a high-powered HEPA machine at a fraction of the initial capital expenditure. Unfortunately, most furnace filters are slid in place without an [[hermetic seal|airtight seal]], which allows air to pass around the filters. This problem is worse for the higher-efficiency MERV filters because of the increase in [[drag (physics)|air resistance]]. Higher-efficiency MERV filters are usually denser and increase air resistance in the central system, requiring a greater [[air pressure]] drop and consequently increasing energy costs.
*[[Activated carbon]] is a [[porosity|porous]] material that can [[adsorption|adsorb]] volatile chemicals on a molecular basis, but does not remove larger particles. The adsorption process when using activated carbon must reach equilibrium thus it may be difficult to completely remove contaminants.<ref name="zeltner" /> Activated carbon is merely a process of changing contaminants from a gaseous phase to a solid phase, when aggravated or disturbed contaminants can be regenerated in indoor air sources.<ref name="lee">{{Cite journal | last1 = Ao | first1 = C. H. | last2 = Lee | first2 = S. C. | doi = 10.1016/S1010-6030(03)00276-4 | title = Combination effect of activated carbon with TiO2 for the photodegradation of binary pollutants at typical indoor air level | journal = Journal of Photochemistry and Photobiology A: Chemistry | volume = 161 | issue = 2–3 | pages = 131 | year = 2004 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> Activated carbon can be used at room temperature and has a long history of commercial use. It is normally used in conjunction with other filter technology, especially with HEPA. Other materials can also absorb chemicals, but at higher cost.
*Polarized-media electronic air cleaners use active electronically enhanced media to combine elements of both electronic air cleaners and passive mechanical filters. Most polarized-media electronic air cleaners use safe 24-volt DC voltage to establish the polarizing electric field. Airborne particles become ionized, or charged, as they pass through the electric field and adhere to a disposable fiber media pad. Ultra-fine particles (UFPs) that are not collected on their initial pass through the media pad are polarized and agglomerate to other particles, odor and VOC molecules and are collected on subsequent passes. The efficiency of polarized-media electronic air cleaners increases as they load, providing high-efficiency filtration, with air resistance typically equal to or less than passive filters. Polarized-media technology is non-ionizing, which means no ozone is produced.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} *Photocatalytic oxidation (PCO) is an emerging technology in the HVAC industry.<ref>[http://www.genesisair.com/documents/PhotocatalysisIAQSensitive.pdf Photocatalysis: Considerations for IAQ-Sensitive Engineering Designs], David J Branson, P.E.., ''Engineered Systems'', April 2006</ref> In addition to the prospect of Indoor Air Quality (IAQ) benefits, it has the added potential for limiting the introduction of unconditioned air to the building space, thereby presenting an opportunity to achieve energy savings over previous prescriptive designs. As of May 2009<ref>[http://www.genesisair.com/documents/FormaldehydeTestReportApril2009.pdf], Formaldehyde Test Report: Genesis Air Populated Catalyst Panel RTI Report Number: A03230901 May 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.genesisair.com/documents/OfficeMixTestReportMay2009.pdf], Office VOC Mixture Test Report: Genesis Air Populated Catalyst Panel RTI Report Number: A03230902, May 2009</ref> there was no more disputable concern raised by the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory data that PCO may significantly increase the amount of formaldehyde in real indoor environments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allergyclean.com/news/uvpcoformaldehyde.htm |title=Study on Photocatalytic Oxidation (PCO) Raises Questions About Formaldehyde as a Byproduct in Indoor Air |work=allergyclean.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426065810/http://allergyclean.com/news/uvpcoformaldehyde.htm |archivedate=2015-04-26 }}</ref> As with other advanced technologies, sound engineering principles and practices should be employed by the HVAC designer to ensure proper application of the technology. [[Photocatalysis|Photocatalytic]] oxidation systems are able to completely oxidize and degrade organic contaminants. For example, Volatile Organic Compounds found low concentrations within a few hundred ppmv or less are the most likely to be completely oxidized.<ref name="zeltner">W.A. Zeltner, D.T. Tompkins. (2005). "Shedding light on photo catalysis". ASHRAE Transactions 3: 523-534.</ref>(PCO) uses short-wave [[ultraviolet]] light (UVC), commonly used for [[sterilization (microbiology)|sterilization]], to energize the catalyst (usually titanium dioxide (TiO2)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/iaq/pubs/residair.html#Photocatalytic_Oxidation_Cleaners|title=Residential Air Cleaners (Second Edition) - Indoor Air - US Environmental Protection Agency|work=epa.gov}}</ref>) and oxidize [[bacteria]] and [[virus]]es.<ref>[https://oildiffuserzone.com/esl-hh-00-05-15.html The Application of Ultraviolet Germicidal Technology in HVAC Systems]{{dead link|date=December 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}, Michael J. Taylor, Product Manager, Carrier Corporation, Syracuse, NY</ref> PCO in-duct units can be mounted to an existing forced-air [[HVAC]] system. PCO is not a filtering technology, as it does not trap or remove particles. It is sometimes coupled with other filtering technologies for air purification. UV sterilization bulbs must be replaced about once a year; manufacturers may require periodic replacement as a condition of [[warranty]]. Photocatalytic Oxidation systems often have high commercial costs.<ref name="zeltner" /> :A related technology relevant to air purification is photoelectrochemical oxidation (PECO) [[Photoelectrochemical oxidation]]. While technically a type of PCO, PECO involves electrochemical interactions among the catalyst material and reactive species (e.g., through emplacement of cathodic materials) to improve quantum efficiency; in this way, it is possible to use lower energy UVA radiation as the light source and yet achieve improved effectiveness.<ref name="goswami">D. Y. Goswami. (2006). "Photoelectrochemical air disinfection" US Patent 7,063,820 B2.</ref> *[[Air ionizer|Ionizer purifiers]] use charged electrical surfaces or needles to generate electrically charged air or gas [[ion]]s. These ions attach to airborne particles which are then [[electrostatic]]ally attracted to a charged collector plate. This mechanism produces trace amounts of [[ozone]] and other oxidants as by-products.<ref name="ang" /> Most ionizers produce less than 0.05 [[parts per million|ppm]] of ozone, an industrial safety standard. There are two major subdivisions: the fanless ionizer and fan-based ionizer. Fanless ionizers are noiseless and use little power, but are less efficient at air purification. Fan-based ionizers clean and distribute air much faster. Permanently mounted home and industrial ionizer purifiers are called [[electrostatic precipitator]]s. *[[Immobilized Cell Technology|Immobilized cell technology]] removes microfine particulate matter from the air by attracting charged particulates to a bio-reactive mass, or bioreactor, which enzymatically renders them inert. *[[Ozone generator]]s are designed to produce ozone, and are sometimes sold as whole house air cleaners. Unlike ionizers, ozone generators are intended to produce significant amounts of ozone, a strong [[oxidant]] gas which can oxidize many other chemicals. The only safe use of ozone generators is in unoccupied rooms, utilising "shock treatment" commercial ozone generators that produce over 3000 mg of ozone per hour. Restoration contractors use these types of ozone generators to remove smoke odors after fire damage, musty smells after flooding, [[mold remediation|mold]] (including [[toxic mold]]s), and the stench caused by decaying flesh which cannot be removed by bleach or anything else except for ozone. However, it is not healthy to breathe ozone gas, and one should use extreme caution when buying a room air purifier that also produces ozone.<ref>[https://www.kent.co.in/air-purifiers/ozone/ Ozone Generators: air cleaners intentionally designed to generate ozone<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104211545/http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/cps-spc/house-domes/electron/cleaners-air-purificateurs-eng.php |date=2010-01-04 }}</ref> *[[Titanium dioxide]] (TiO<sub>2</sub>) technology - [[nanoparticles]] of TiO<sub>2</sub>, together with [[Limestone|calcium carbonate]] to neutralize any [[acid]]ic gasses that may be adsorbed, is mixed into slightly porous paint. [[Photocatalysis]] initiates the decomposition of airborne contaminants at the surface.<ref>{{Cite journal |last = Hogan |first = Jenny| title = Smog-busting paint soaks up noxious gases |journal = [[New Scientist]] |publisher = Reed Business Information |location = London |date = 4 February 2004 |accessdate = }}</ref>
==Consumer concerns== Other aspects of air cleaners are hazardous gaseous by-products, noise level, frequency of filter replacement, electrical consumption, and visual appeal. Ozone production is typical for air ionizing purifiers. Although high concentration of ozone is dangerous, most air ionizers produce low amounts (< 0.05 ppm). The noise level of a purifier can be obtained through a customer service department and is usually reported in [[decibel]]s (dB). The noise levels for most purifiers are low compared to many other home appliances.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} Frequency of filter replacement and electrical consumption are the major operation costs for any purifier. There are many types of filters; some can be cleaned by water, by hand or by [[vacuum cleaner]], while others need to be replaced every few months or years. In the United States, some purifiers are certified as [[Energy Star]] and are [[efficient energy use|energy efficient]].
HEPA technology is used in portable air purifiers as it removes common airborne allergens. The [[United States Department of Energy|US Department of Energy]] has requirements manufacturers must pass to meet HEPA requirements. The HEPA specification requires removal of at least 99.97% of 0.3 micrometers airborne pollutants. Products that claim to be "HEPA-type", "HEPA-like", or "99% HEPA" do not satisfy these requirements and may not have been tested in independent laboratories.
Air purifiers may be rated on a variety of factors, including [[Clean Air Delivery Rate]] (which determines how well air has been purified); efficient area coverage; [[air changes per hour]]; energy usage; and the cost of the replacement filters. Two other important factors to consider are the length that the filters are expected to last (measured in months or years) and the noise produced (measured in [[decibel]]s) by the various settings that the purifier runs on. This information is available from most manufacturers.
==Potential ozone hazards== As with other health-related appliances, there is controversy surrounding the claims of certain companies, especially involving [[air ioniser|ionic air purifiers]]. Many air purifiers generate some ozone, an energetic [[allotrope]] of three [[oxygen]] atoms, and in the presence of humidity, small amounts of [[nitrogen oxide|NO<sub>x</sub>]]. Because of the nature of the ionization process, ionic air purifiers tend to generate the most ozone.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} This is a serious concern, because ozone is a [[criteria air pollutant]] regulated by health-related US federal and state standards. In a controlled experiment, in many cases, ozone concentrations were well in excess of public and/or industrial safety levels established by US Environmental Protection Agency, particularly in poorly ventilated rooms.<ref>{{cite journal| title=Quantification of Ozone Levels in Indoor Environments Generated by Ionization and Ozonolysis Air Purifiers|author1=Britigan, Nicole |author2=Alshawa, Ahmad |author3=Nizkorodov, Sergey A. | journal=Journal of the Air & Waste Management Association|date=May 2006| volume=56| pages=601–610| ISSN=1047-3289| pmid=16739796| issue=5| doi=10.1080/10473289.2006.10464467}}</ref>
Ozone can damage the lungs, causing chest pain, coughing, shortness of breath and throat irritation. It can also worsen chronic respiratory diseases such as asthma and compromise the ability of the body to fight respiratory infections—even in healthy people. People who have asthma and allergy are most prone to the adverse effects of high levels of ozone.<!-- {{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} --><ref>{{cite web|title=Health Effects of Ozone in Patients with Asthma |url=http://www.epa.gov/o3healthtraining/effects.html |work=US Environmental Protection Agency |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608003704/http://www.epa.gov/o3healthtraining/effects.html |archivedate=2011-06-08 }}</ref> For example, increasing ozone concentrations to unsafe levels can increase the risk of asthma attacks.
Due to the below average performance and potential health risks, [[Consumer Reports]] has advised against using ozone producing air purifiers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/appliances/heating-cooling-and-air/air-cleaners/air-purifiers-sub/ozone-generators/ozone-generators-not-acceptable.htm |title=Consumer Reports Article: Not Acceptable: Ozone generators |accessdate=8 August 2013|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071116141711/http://www.consumerreports.org/cro/appliances/heating-cooling-and-air/air-cleaners/air-purifiers-sub/ozone-generators/ozone-generators-not-acceptable.htm |archivedate = 2007-11-16}}</ref> [[IQAir]], the educational partner of the American Lung Association, has been a leading industry voice against ozone-producing air cleaning technology.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ozone: What Air Cleaner Advertisers Don't Tell You |url=http://www.swedeclean.com/scandinavia/consumer/ozone.html |work=Swede Clean |author1=Frank Hammes |author2=President of IQAir |access-date=2013-10-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210042930/http://www.swedeclean.com/scandinavia/consumer/ozone.html |archive-date=2015-02-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
[[Ozone]] generators used for shock treatments (unoccupied rooms) which are needed by smoke, mold, and odor remediation contractors as well as crime scene cleanup companies to oxidize and permanently remove smoke, mold, and odor damage are considered a valuable and effective tool when used correctly for commercial and industrial purposes. However, there is a growing body of evidence that these machines can produce undesirable by-products.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ozone Generators that are Sold as Air Cleaners|url=http://www.epa.gov/indoor-air-quality-iaq/ozone-generators-are-sold-air-cleaners|publisher=US Environmental Protection Agency}}</ref>
In September 2007, the California Air Resources Board announced a ban of indoor air cleaning devices which produce ozone above a legal limit. This law, which took effect in 2010, requires testing and certification of all types of indoor air cleaning devices to verify that they do not emit excessive ozone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/research/indoor/aircleaners/aircleaners.htm|title=AB 2276 Air Cleaner Regulation|access-date=2016-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite act |title=AB-2276 Ozone: indoor air cleaning devices. |type=Act |number=2276 |date=29 September 2006 |url=http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=200520060AB2276 |accessdate=2016-02-06 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Air filter]] *[[Air ioniser]] *[[Air sanitizer]] *[[Electrostatic precipitator]] *[[HEPA]] *[[Nose filter]] *[[NASA Clean Air Study]] *[[Ozone generator]]

{{Multiple issues|{{COI|date=September 2016}}{{primary sources|date=September 2016}}}} {{Infobox organization |name=American Wood Council |image=American_Wood_Council_Logo.jpg |established = 2010 |headquarters = Leesburg, VA |leader_title = CEO |leader_name = Robert Glowinski |website = [http://www.awc.org awc.org] }}
The '''American Wood Council''' (AWC) is a trade association that represents over 75 percent of North American wood products manufacturers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reusewood.org/guide/topics/american-wood-council|title=About American Wood Council| publisher=Reuse Wood Directory| date=2015}}</ref>
North American membership includes companies and industry associations; among them, [[Boise Cascade]] LLC, [[Canfor]] USA/New South, [[Georgia-Pacific]] LLC, [[Interfor Corporation]], [[Kapstone]], [[Louisiana Pacific]], [[Masonite]], [[Norbord]] Inc., [[Plum Creek Timber]], [[Potlatch Corp.]], [[Sierra Pacific Industries]], [[West Fraser]], West Rock Company, [[Weyerhaeuser]] Company, and the Canadian Wood Council.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://awc.org/aboutus/members-board| title=Members/Board| publisher=American Wood Council| date=2016}}</ref>
==History== AWC was re-chartered in June 2010, with a broader mandate than a former predecessor namesake.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hbsdealer.com/article/boise-cascade-ceo-takes-helm-awc| title=HBS Dealer| publisher=Hardware+Building Supply Dealer}}</ref> Up until 2010, the wood products industry was represented by the [[American Forest & Paper Association]] (AF&PA), which now represents pulp and paper manufacturers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://afandpa.org/our-industry/history-of-af-pa-and-our-industry| title=History of AF&PA and our Industry| publisher=American Forest & Paper Association| date=2015}}</ref>

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Amoco Cadiz'' oil spill}} [[File:Amoco Cadiz 2.jpg|thumb|right|''Amoco Cadiz'' and coast of Brittany.]] The [[oil tanker]] ''[[Amoco Cadiz]]'' ran aground on [[Portsall|Portsall Rocks]], {{convert|5|km|abbr=on}} from the coast of [[Brittany]], France, on 16 March 1978, and ultimately split in three and sank, all together resulting in the [[largest oil spill]] of its kind in history to that date.<ref name="ctx"/><ref name="aukevisser">{{cite web | author=Auke Visser | title=Amoco Cadiz | url=http://www.aukevisser.nl/supertankers/part-1/id532.htm | publisher=International Super Tankers | date=26 August 2010 | accessdate=9 September 2010}}</ref>
[[NOAA]] estimates that the total oil spill amounted to 220,880 metric tonnes of oil.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oil spill - Amoco Cadiz|url=https://incidentnews.noaa.gov/incident/6241|website=incidentnews.noaa.gov|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=7 May 2018}}</ref>
==Sequence of events== En route from the [[Persian Gulf]] to [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]], via a scheduled stop at [[Lyme Bay]], Great Britain, the ship encountered stormy weather with gale conditions and high seas while in the [[English Channel]]. At around 09:45, a heavy wave slammed into the ship's [[rudder]] and it was found that she was no longer responding to the helm. This was due to the shearing of [[British Standard Whitworth|Whitworth thread]] studs in the Hastie four ram steering gear, built under licence in Spain, causing a loss of [[hydraulic fluid]]. Attempts to repair the damage and regain control of the ship were made but proved unsuccessful. While the message "no longer manoeuvrable" and asking other vessels to stand by was transmitted at 10:20, no call for [[Tugboat|tug]] assistance was issued until 11:20.<ref name="ctx">{{cite web| title=''Amoco Cadiz'' (IMO 7336422): Summary for Casualty ID 19780316_001| url=http://www.c4tx.org/ctx/job/cdb/precis.php5?key=19780316_001 | work=Casualty Database| publisher=Center for Tankship Excellence| accessdate=16 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="Lagadec">{{cite book | author=Patrick Lagadec | title=Major Technological Risk - An Assessment of Industrial Disasters | year=1982 | format=Oxford; New York | publisher=Pergamon Press | url=http://www.patricklagadec.net/fr/pdf/Amoco_Cadiz_EN.pdf | isbn=0-08-028913-4 | accessdate=11 June 2010}}</ref>
The German tug ''Pacific'' responded to ''Amoco Cadiz'' at 11:28, offering assistance under a [[Lloyd's Open Form]] (see below). It arrived on the scene at 12:20, but because of the stormy sea, a tow line was not in place until 14:00, and broke off at 16:15. Several attempts were made to establish another tow line and ''Amoco Cadiz'' dropped its anchor trying to halt its drift. A successful tow line was in place at 20:55,<ref name="Lagadec"/> but this measure proved incapable of preventing the supertanker from drifting towards the coast because of its huge mass and [[Beaufort scale|Force 10]] storm winds.<ref name="pandora">{{cite web | author=Boileau, David |author2=Allen, Tony|author3= Claes, Johnny | title=Amoco Cadiz (+1978) | url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?10339 | work=The Wrecksite Archive | date=4 July 2009 | accessdate=11 June 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110924094606/http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?10339|archivedate=24 September 2011}}</ref>
At 21:04 ''Amoco Cadiz'' ran aground the first time, flooding its engines, and again at 21:39, this time ripping open the hull and starting the oil spill. Her crew was rescued by [[French Naval Aviation]] helicopters at midnight, and her captain and one officer remained aboard until 05:00 the next morning.<ref name="Lagadec"/>
At 10:00 on 17 March the vessel broke in two, releasing its entire cargo of {{convert|1.6|Moilbbl|m3}} of oil, and broke again eleven days later from the buffeting of high stormy seas. The wreckage was later completely destroyed with depth charges by the [[French Navy]].<ref name="pandora"/>
==Lloyd's Open Form== An argument arose between the captain of ''Amoco Cadiz'', Pasquale Bardari, and that of the captain of the German tug ''Pacific'', Hartmut Weinert, on the issue of [[Lloyd's Open Form]] (LOF). Captain Weinert thought this a classic LOF case, an oil tanker with damage to its steering gear, rough weather and getting closer to the shore by the minute.
At the time of the accident, the ship and the cargo were valued at about {{US$|40 million}}, so Captain Weinert's company could, in the event of success, have received a large award. Captain Bardari of the Cadiz, on the instructions of his owners, wanted "....towage rate to Lyme Bay."
The argument dragged on from 11:28 when ''Pacific'' first made contact with ''Amoco Cadiz'' until 16:00 when Captain Bardari finally received approval to accept the LOF from the ship's owners in [[Chicago]]. However, this dispute did not delay the salvage operation significantly, because tugging preparations had already started. Captain Weinert was aware that if he were to succeed in bringing the tanker into Lyme Bay on the English coast, his owners could arrest the ship in the English High Court in pursuit of a claim for salvage.
It was incorrectly reported in the press at the time that, after long negotiations on financial terms between the ship's captain and the master of a West German tugboat and two unsuccessful towing attempts, the towline finally broke during the argument and the ship drifted onto the rocks. This version of events became fixed in the public mind although in fact delay was caused by Captain Bardari of ''Amoco Cadiz'' contacting her owners in Chicago for instructions. The delay in sending a distress message meant that the larger tug ''Seefalke'', which might have been in range an hour earlier, was no longer nearby when the distress call was made.<ref name="ctx"/>
==Oil spill== {{more citations needed|section|date=March 2014}} ''Amoco Cadiz'' contained 1,604,500 [[Barrel (unit)|barrels]] (219,797 tons) of [[light crude oil]] from [[Ras Tanura]], [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[Kharg Island]], [[Iran]].<ref name="pandora"/> Additionally, she had nearly 4,000 tonnes bunker oil. Severe weather resulted in the complete breakup of the ship before any oil could be pumped out of the wreck, resulting in its entire cargo of crude oil (belonging to [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]]) and 4,000 tons of [[fuel oil]] being spilled into the sea.<ref name ="Helgoland Marine Research">{{cite journal | last=Hartog | first=C. den | last2=Jacobs |first2=R. P. W. M. | title=Effects of the ''Amoco Cadiz'' Oil Spill on an Eelgrass Community at Roscoff (France) with special reference to the mobile benthic fauna | journal=Helgoland Marine Research | publisher=Springer Berlin / Heidelberg | volume=33 | issue=1-4 | pages=182–191 | doi=10.1007/BF02414745 |date = March 1980| url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/x427513224718740/ | accessdate=11 June 2010}}</ref>
A {{convert|12|mi|abbr=on}} long slick and heavy pools of oil spread onto {{convert|45|mi|abbr=on}} of the French shoreline by northwesterly winds. Prevailing westerly winds during the following month spread the oil approximately {{convert|100|mi|abbr=on}} east along the coast. One week after the accident, oil had reached [[Côtes d'Armor]].
Oil penetrated the sand on several beaches to a depth of {{convert|20|in|mm|-2}}. Sub-surface oil separated into two or three layers due to the extensive sand transfer that occurred on the beaches during rough weather. Piers and slips in the small harbors from [[Porspoder]] to [[Île-de-Bréhat|Brehat Island]] were covered with oil. Other affected areas included the pink granite rock beaches of [[Trégastel]] and [[Perros-Guirec]], as well as the tourist beaches at [[Plougasnou]]. The total extent of oiling one month after the spill included approximately {{convert|200|mi|km}} of coastline. Beaches of 76 different [[Brittany|Breton]] communities were oiled.
Oil persisted for only a few weeks along the exposed rocky shores that experienced moderate to high wave action. In the areas sheltered from wave action, however, the oil persisted in the form of an asphalt crust for several years.
[[File:Amoco Cadiz impact.jpg|thumb|right|Oiled beach in Brittany.]] The isolated location of the grounding and rough seas hampered cleanup efforts for the two weeks following the incident.
As mandated in the "[[Polmar Plan]]", the [[French Navy]] was responsible for all offshore operations while the [[Civil Safety Service]] was responsible for shore cleanup activities. Although the total quantity of collected oil and water reached 100,000 tons, less than 20,000 tons of oil were recovered from this liquid after treatment in refining plants.
The nature of the oil and rough seas contributed to the rapid formation of a "chocolate mousse" [[emulsification]] of oil and water. This viscous emulsification greatly complicated the cleanup efforts. French authorities decided not to use dispersants in sensitive areas or the coastal fringe where water depth was less than {{convert|50|m|ft}}. Had dispersant been applied from the air in the vicinity of the spill source, the formation of mousse might have been prevented.
At the time, ''Amoco Cadiz ''incident resulted in the largest loss of marine life ever recorded from an oil spill. Mortalities of most animals occurred over the two months following the spill. Two weeks following the accident, millions of dead [[mollusc]]s, [[sea urchin]]s, and other bottom dwelling organisms washed ashore.
Diving birds constituted the majority of the nearly 20,000 dead birds that were recovered. The [[oyster]] mortality from the spill was estimated at 9,000 tons. Fishermen in the area caught fish with skin ulcerations and tumors.
Some of the fish caught in the area reportedly had a strong taste of petroleum. Although [[echinoderm]] and small [[crustacean]] populations almost completely disappeared, the populations of many species recovered within a year. Cleanup activities on rocky shores, such as pressure-washing, also caused habitat impacts.
The ''Amoco Cadiz'' spill was one of the most studied oil spills in history. Many studies remain in progress. This was the largest recorded spill in history and was the first spill in which [[estuarine]] tidal rivers were oiled. No follow-up mitigation existed to deal with asphalt formation and problems that resulted after the initial aggressive cleanup.
Additional erosion of beaches occurred in several places where no attempt was made to restore the gravel that was removed to lower the beach face. Many of the affected marshes, mudflats, and sandy beaches, were low-energy areas. Evidence of oiled beach sediments can still be seen in some of these sheltered areas. Layers of sub-surface oil still remain buried in many of the impacted beaches.
==Culture== The ship and spill features in one of [[Steve Forbert]]'s songs about oil pollution.<ref>{{cite interview | subject=Steve Forbert | interviewer=Mike Ragogna | title=Oil and Music: Conversations With Steve Forbert and Tift Merritt | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mike-ragogna/emoil-and-musicem-convers_b_592938.html?view=print | type=Interview: transcript | work=The Huffington Post | date=28 May 2010 | accessdate=11 June 2010}}</ref> [[Speedy J]] has a song named "Amoco Cadiz" on his album ''A Shocking Hobby''. French popstar [[Alain Barriere]] had a disco hit in France with a song called "Amoco".<ref>{{cite | title=Discogs.com | url= http://www.discogs.com/Alain-Barriere-Amoco/release/4368118}}</ref>
==Legal claims== In 1978, it was estimated to have caused US$250 million in damage to fisheries and tourist amenities. The French government presented claims totalling 1.9 billion french francs to United States courts (using the 1978 exchange rate and with interest added this came to at least US$1.6 billion). In 1984, U.S. District Court Judge Frank J. McGarr held that Amoco was liable for damages when he issued his trial verdict, after 3 1/2 years of legal proceedings. Further, the judge ruled that Amoco had put off needed maintenance on the vessel in order to keep it at sea.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-01-12/business/8803210819_1_amoco-cadiz-mcgarr-french-law], http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-01-12/business/8803210819_1_amoco-cadiz-mcgarr-french-law (accessed May 15th 2018)</ref>
In 1992, US oil giant Amoco has decided not to appeal against the US court order that it must pay US$200 million to the French government. <ref>[http://www.insurance-times.net/article/amoco-agrees-pay-us230m], http://www.insurance-times.net/article/amoco-agrees-pay-us230m (accessed May 15th 2018). </ref>
==See also== *''[[Torrey Canyon oil spill]]'' - nearby and similar disaster in 1967 *''[[MT Haven]]'' - formerly ''Amoco Milford Haven'', sister ship of ''Amoco Cadiz'' that also sank and caused an oil spill disaster. *[[List of oil spills]]

[[File:Wea01422.jpg|thumb|right|The "Black Sunday" dust storm approaches [[Spearman, Texas|Spearman]] in northern [[Texas]], April 14, 1935.]] '''Black Sunday''' refers to a particularly severe [[dust storm]] that occurred on April 14, 1935, as part of the [[Dust Bowl]].{{cite web|title=The Black Sunday Dust Storm of 14 April 1935|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=blacksunday|publisher=National Weather Service: Norman, Oklahoma Weather Forecast Office|accessdate=23 May 2012}} It was one of the worst dust storms in American history and it caused immense economic and agricultural damage.{{cite web|title=Black Sunday: April 14, 1935|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/features/general-article/dustbowl-black-sunday|publisher=PBS|accessdate=24 May 2012}} It is estimated to have displaced 300 million tons of topsoil from the prairie area in the US.''Black Blizzard'', History Channel documentary. On the afternoon of April 14, the residents of the Plains States were forced to take cover as a dust storm, or "black blizzard", blew through the region. The storm hit the [[Oklahoma Panhandle]] and [[Northwestern Oklahoma]] first, and moved south for the remainder of the day. It hit [[Beaver, Oklahoma|Beaver]] around 4:00 p.m., [[Boise City, Oklahoma|Boise City]] around 5:15 p.m., and [[Amarillo, Texas]], at 7:20 p.m. The conditions were the most severe in the Oklahoma and [[Texas panhandle]]s, but the storm's effects were felt in other surrounding areas. The storm was harsh due to the high winds that hit the area that day. The combination of drought, erosion, bare soil, and winds caused the dust to fly freely and at high speeds.{{cite web|title=The Dust Bowl Drought|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/paleo/drought/drght_history.html|work=Drought: A Paleo Perspective -- 20th Century Drought|accessdate=24 May 2012}} == The Dust Bowl == {{Main|Dust Bowl}} In North America, the term "Dust Bowl" was first used to describe a series of dust storms that hit the [[prairie]]s of [[Canada]] and the [[United States]] during the 1930s, and later to describe the area in the United States that was most affected by the storms, including western Kansas, eastern Colorado, northeastern New Mexico, and the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles.{{cite web|title=Dust Bowl 1931–1939|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/article-1G2-3424800020/dust-bowl-1931-1939.html|work=Historic Events for Students: The Great Depression|publisher=Encyclopedia.com|accessdate=22 May 2012}} The "black blizzards" started in the Eastern states in 1930, affecting agriculture from [[Maine]] to [[Arkansas]]. By 1934 they had reached the [[Great Plains]], stretching from North Dakota to Texas, and from the [[Mississippi embayment|Mississippi River Valley]] to the [[Rocky Mountains]].{{cite book|last=Watkins|first=T. H.|title=The Dust Bowl|year=2003|publisher=Greenhaven Press|chapter=Prosperity, Depression, and War: 1920–1945|pages=162–170}} "The Dust Bowl" (as an area) received its name following the disastrous "Black Sunday" storm in April 1935, when reporter Robert L. Geiger referred to the region as "The Dust Bowl" in his account of the storm. == Causes == {{Details|Dust Bowl#Causes}} [[Cattle]] farming and [[Sheep husbandry|sheep ranching]] had left much of the West devoid of natural grass and shrubs to anchor the soil, and over-farming and poor soil stewardship left the soil dehydrated and lacking in organic matter. During a massive [[drought]] that hit the United States in the 1930s, the lack of rainfall, snowfall, and moisture in the air dried out the top soil in most of the country's farming regions. == Effects == The destruction caused by the dust storms, and especially by the storm on Black Sunday, killed multiple people {{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} and caused hundreds of thousands of people to relocate. Poor migrants from the American Southwest (known as "[[Okie]]s" - though only about 20 percent were from Oklahoma) flooded California, overtaxing the state's health and employment infrastructure.{{cite web|last=Trimarchi|first=Maria|title=What Caused the Dust Bowl?|url=http://science.howstuffworks.com/environmental/green-science/dust-bowl-cause2.html|publisher=HowStuffWorks|accessdate=19 May 2012}} In 1935, after the massive damage caused by these storms, Congress passed the [[Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act of 1936|Soil Conservation Act]], which established the [[Natural Resources Conservation Service|Soil Conservation Service]] (SCS) as a permanent agency of the [[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]].{{cite web|title=USDA Is Celebrating 150 Years|url=http://www.in.nrcs.usda.gov|publisher=Indiana NRCS|accessdate=19 May 2012}} The SCS was created in an attempt to provide guidance for land owners and land users to reduce soil erosion, improve forest and field land and conserve and develop natural resources.{{cite web|title=NRCS Fact Sheet |url=http://www.me.nrcs.usda.gov/about/FactSheet.html |publisher=Maine NCRS |accessdate=20 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130214164232/http://www.me.nrcs.usda.gov/about/FactSheet.html |archivedate=14 February 2013 |df= }} == Personal accounts of Black Sunday and other dust storms == During the 1930s, many residents of the Dust Bowl kept accounts and journals of their lives and of the storms that hit their areas. Collections of accounts of the dust storms during the 1930s have been compiled over the years and are now available in book collections and online. {{quote|text="People caught in their own yards grope for the doorstep. Cars come to a standstill, for no light in the world can penetrate that swirling murk…. The nightmare is deepest during the storms. But on the occasional bright day and the usual gray day we cannot shake from it. We live with the dust, eat it, sleep with it, watch it strip us of possessions and the hope of possessions."|sign=Avis D. Carlson|source=[[The New Republic]]}} Lawrence Svobida was a [[wheat]] farmer in Kansas during the 1930s. He experienced the period of dust storms, and the effect that they had on the surrounding environment and the society. His observations and feelings are available in his memoirs, ''Farming the Dust Bowl''. Here he describes an approaching dust storm: {{quote|text="… At other times a cloud is seen to be approaching from a distance of many miles. Already it has the banked appearance of a cumulus cloud, but it is black instead of white and it hangs low, seeming to hug the earth. Instead of being slow to change its form, it appears to be rolling on itself from the crest downward. As it sweeps onward, the landscape is progressively blotted out. Birds fly in terror before the storm, and only those that are strong of wing may escape. The smaller birds fly until they are exhausted, then fall to the ground, to share the fate of the thousands of jack rabbits which perish from suffocation."}} The Black Sunday storm is detailed in the 2012 [[Ken Burns]] PBS documentary ''[[The Dust Bowl (film)|The Dust Bowl]]''. == Media references == Musicians and songwriters began to reflect the Dust Bowl and the events of the 1930s in their music. [[Woody Guthrie]], a singer-songwriter from Oklahoma, wrote a variety of songs documenting his experiences living during the era of dust storms. Several were collected in his first album ''[[Dust Bowl Ballads]]''. One of them, ''Great Dust Storm'', describes the events of Black Sunday. An excerpt of the lyrics follows: ''On the 14th day of April of 1935,
''There struck the worst of dust storms that ever filled the sky.
''You could see that dust storm comin', the cloud looked deathlike black,
''And through our mighty nation, it left a dreadful track.
''From Oklahoma City to the Arizona line,
''Dakota and Nebraska to the lazy Rio Grande,
''It fell across our city like a curtain of black rolled down,
''We thought it was our judgement, we thought it was our doom. Musician Kat Eggleston has written a play, ''The Cyclone Line'', about her father Al Eggleston's experiences growing up in 1930s Oklahoma, Black Sunday, and the Dust Bowl in general. Its first public performances were on [[Vashon, Washington|Vashon (Island), Washington]], where he lived most of his life.{{Cite web|url=http://vashonalliedarts.org/the-cyclone-line-a-play-by-kat-eggleston/|title=The Cyclone Line, a play by Kat Eggleston « Vashon Center for the Arts|website=vashonalliedarts.org|access-date=November 2, 2016}} Americana recording artist [[Grant Maloy Smith]] released an album in 2017 called ''Dust Bowl – American Stories'' that featured two songs that directly referenced Black Sunday. The song "Old Black Roller" is written from a first person perspective during the Black Sunday storm, and another song "Never Seen The Rain" has these chorus lyrics: "We worked the land to death, me and my brother | 'Til April 14, 1935 | Oklahoma, you were like our mother - oh, my" American recording artist [[Gillian Welch]] refers to the storm and other historical events in a two-part song on her 2001 album ''[[Time (The Revelator)]]'': "April the 14th Part I" and "Ruination Day Part II". ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Droughts in the United States]] [[Category:Dust storms]] [[Category:Weather hazards]] [[Category:Dust Bowl]] [[Category:1935 natural disasters in the United States]] [[Category:1935 in Texas]] [[Category:Natural disasters in Texas]]

{{main|Bolloré Bluecar}} [[File:Bolloré Bluecar Bluecity car share in London 001.jpg|thumb|right|Bolloré Bluecar Bluecity car share in Hammersmith, London]] The service uses the all electric [[Bolloré Bluecar]],<ref>{{cite web | last=Lunn | first=Emma | title=Powering ahead: the new breed of electric car clubs | website=The Guardian | date=August 18, 2018 | url=http://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/aug/18/electric-car-clubs-emissions-range | access-date=September 19, 2018}}</ref> which were adapted to suit London's [[Left- and right-hand traffic|left-hand traffic]]. {{Infobox film | name = Boom Town | image = Boom Town poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | based on = {{based on|''A Lady Comes to Burkburnett'' in
''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'' magazine (August 1939)|[[James Edward Grant]]}} | writer = [[John Lee Mahin]] | starring = [[Clark Gable]]
[[Spencer Tracy]]
[[Claudette Colbert]]
[[Hedy Lamarr]] | director = [[Jack Conway (filmmaker)|Jack Conway]] | producer = [[Sam Zimbalist]] | editing = [[Blanche Sewell]]
[[Paul Landres]] ''(uncredited)'' | studio = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | distributor = [[Loews Cineplex Entertainment|Loew's Incorporated]] | released = {{Film date|1940|08|08|''LA''{{cite web |url=http://www.graumanschinese.org/1940.html |title=1940 |last= |first= |date= |website=graumanschinese.org |publisher= |accessdate=December 2, 2015 }}}} | runtime = 119 minutes | language = English | country = United States | music = [[Franz Waxman]] | cinematography = [[Harold Rosson]]
[[Elwood Bredell]] ''(uncredited)'' | budget = $1.6 million{{Citation | title = The Eddie Mannix Ledger | publisher = Margaret Herrick Library, Center for Motion Picture Study | place = Los Angeles}}. |gross = $5 million }} '''''Boom Town''''' is a 1940 American [[adventure film]] directed by [[Jack Conway (filmmaker)|Jack Conway]] and starring [[Clark Gable]], [[Spencer Tracy]], [[Claudette Colbert]], and [[Hedy Lamarr]]. The supporting cast features [[Frank Morgan]], [[Lionel Atwill]], and [[Chill Wills]]. A story written by [[James Edward Grant]] in ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'' magazine entitled "A Lady Comes to [[Burkburnett, Texas|Burkburnett]]" provided the inspiration for the film.[http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/heb14 "Burkburnett, TX"] on the Texas State Historical Association website The film was produced and released by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]. ==Plot== "Big John" McMasters ([[Clark Gable]]) and "Square John" Sand ([[Spencer Tracy]]) are two down-on-their-luck oil [[Wildcatter|wildcat]]ters who join forces. Without enough money, they steal drilling equipment from a skeptical Luther Aldrich ([[Frank Morgan]]). Their well proves a bust and they have to hastily depart when Aldrich shows up with the sheriff to take back his property. The two oilmen team up and make enough money to partially pay Aldrich. To get him to back them for a second try, they cut him in for a percentage of the well. This time, they strike it rich. When Elizabeth 'Betsy' Bartlett ([[Claudette Colbert]]) shows up, McMasters sweeps her off her feet (without knowing that Sand considers her his girl) and marries her. Sand accepts the situation, wanting Betsy to be happy. However, on their first anniversary, she catches her husband dancing with a barroom floozy. As a result, Sand quarrels with McMasters and they flip a coin for the entire oilfield. Betsy leaves too, but returns when she learns that her husband has lost almost everything to Sand and needs her. Each man goes through booms and busts. Building on his renewed success as a wildcatter, McMasters moves to New York to expand into refineries and distribution, competing against former customer Harry Compton ([[Lionel Atwill]]). Seeking inside information about his rivals, he hires away Compton's adviser Karen Vanmeer ([[Hedy Lamarr]]), who uses her social contacts and womanly charms to gather industry information. Meanwhile, Sand loses everything he has built up in South America to a revolution. When he meets McMasters at an oilmen's convention, the two finally reconcile, and Sand goes to work for his old friend. When he suspects that McMasters is carrying on an affair with Karen, he tries to save Betsy's marriage by offering to marry Karen. However, she deduces his motives and declines. When a miserable Betsy tries to commit suicide by taking sleeping pills, Sand decides that the only way to help her is to bankrupt McMasters. Sand loses his costly battle with his former friend and goes broke. It is only when he asks McMasters to give his wife a divorce that the married man finally comes to his senses. Later, McMasters is prosecuted by the government for violating the [[Sherman Antitrust Act]] and loses his business. In the end, poor, but happier, Sand and McMasters team up again, with the blissful Betsy looking on. Aldrich supplies them with equipment and the whole cycle begins again. ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Clark Gable]] as "Big John" McMasters * [[Spencer Tracy]] as "Square John" Sand * [[Claudette Colbert]] as Betsy Bartlett McMasters {{nb10}} * [[Hedy Lamarr]] as Karen Vanmeer * [[Frank Morgan]] as Luther Aldrich * [[Lionel Atwill]] as Harry Compton * [[Chill Wills]] as Deputy Harmony Jones * [[Marion Martin]] as Whitey * [[Minna Gombell]] as Evie * [[Joe Yule]] as Ed Murphy * [[Horace Murphy]] as Tom Murphy * Roy Gordon as "Mac" McCreery * [[Richard Lane (actor)|Richard Lane]] as Assistant District Attorney * Casey Johnson as Jack McMasters as a child * Baby Quintanilla as Jack McMasters as a baby * [[George Lessey]] as Judge * [[Sara Haden]] as Miss Barnes * [[Frank Orth]] as Barber * [[Frank McGlynn Sr.]] as Deacon * [[Curt Bois]] as Ferdie * [[Howard Hickman]] as McCreery's associate #1 (uncredited) {{div col end}} '''Cast notes:''' *Gable's father, William Gable, was an oil-well driller and as a teenager Gable himself worked for his father in [[Oklahoma]], so he was familiar with the subject of this film.D'Onofrio, Joseph. [http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/57/Boom-Town/articles.html "Boom Town (1940)"] on [[TCM.com]] ==Production== [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM]] had been looking for a project set in the oil fields as a vehicle for Clarke Gable for some time. They optioned the short story "The Lady Comes to Burkburnett" in November 1938.Schallert, Edwin (November 18, 1938) "'Boom Town' Looms for Gable and Tracy" ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' p.A7Staff (November 23, 1938) "Goldwyn Seeks to Buy 'The Raven' for Gary Cooper--Universal Engages Princess Baba for Comedy Of Local Origin" ''[[The New York Times]]'' p.25 The actress originally considered for the female lead role was [[Myrna Loy]], for whom the part was written.[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/57/Boom-Town/notes.html "Notes"] on [[TCM.com]].Churchill, Douglas W. (November 18, 1939) "Madeleine Carroll Gets Lead in 'My Son, My Son,' and 'Northwest Mounted Police' Ruth Gordon in 'Disraeli' Gets Role of Queen Victoria Opposite Olivier -- 'Beasts of Berlin' at Globe Today Of Local Origin" ''[[The New York Times]]'' p.22 The role went to Claudette Colbert instead, the second, and last, pairing of Colbert and Gable, who had appeared together in ''[[It Happened One Night]]''. Gable and Spencer Tracy had also worked together before, in two other films, ''[[San Francisco (1936 film)|San Francisco]]'' and ''[[Test Pilot (film)|Test Pilot]]''. Eventually Tracy insisted on the same [[Billing (filmmaking)|top billing]] clause in his MGM contract that Gable enjoyed, effectively ending the pairing, though Tracy and Gable liked each other personally and enjoyed working together. The movie was the first Gable made under a new seven-year contract with MGM.Scheur, Philip K. (January 26, 1940) "Metro Gives Gable New Seven-Year Contract: Tilton Sings in 'Irene' R.K.O., Massey in Deal Rutherford, Hunt Cast 'Embezzler' Announced Kosleck With Paramount" ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' p.13.Churchill, Douglas W. (January 26, 1940) "Metro Signs Gable in $2,000,000 Deal: Actor's Seven-Year Contract Starts at $5,000 Weekly-- Calls for 52 Weeks a Year 'Fighting 69th' at Strand Opens Today Starring Cagney and O'Brien--'Brother Rat and a Baby' at the Roxy Ann Rutherford Gets Role Warners Buy Cain's Story Of Local Origin" ''[[The New York Times]]'' p.20 Tracy, in fact, brooded over his second-billing status during the filming of ''Boom Town'' and was reportedly unpleasant to deal with. He especially did not get along with either of the female leads. Some of the location shooting for the film took place in [[Bakersfield, California]]. ==Reception== ===Critical=== [[Bosley Crowther]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised the scenes involving the oil wells as exciting but found the human part of the story "peters out into repetitious wrangling along monotonous lines."{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9F01EEDF103EE432A25755C0A96F9C946193D6CF |title=Movie Review - Boom Town |last=Crowther |first=Bosley |authorlink=Bosley Crowther |date=September 6, 1940 |website=[[The New York Times]] |publisher= |accessdate=December 2, 2015 }} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'''s review was positive, writing: "Unlike many large-budgeted productions carrying multistar setups that tend either to costume background or sophistication for limited appeal, this one breaks out with a dashing, rough-and-tumble yarn of modern adventure that carries all elements for widest audience appeal ... story is repetitious in its cutbacks to new oil fields and gushers, but this fact will be considered unimportant by the customers."{{cite magazine |last= |first= |date=August 7, 1940 |title=Boom Town |url= |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |location=New York |publisher=Variety, Inc. |page=14 |accessdate= }} ''[[Harrison's Reports]]'' accurately predicted that the film's star power would make it a big hit, but said the story was "only fairly good" and the plot "somewhat thin."{{cite journal |last= |first= |date=August 17, 1940 |title='Boom Town' with Clark Gable, Spencer Tracy, Claudette Colbert and Hedy Lamarr |url= |journal=[[Harrison's Reports]] |location= |publisher= |page=131 |accessdate= }} ''[[Film Daily]]'' called the screenplay "excellent" and wrote that Conway "has furnished an outstanding job of directing, blending the action, love interest and comedy so that interest is held to the end."{{cite journal |last= |first= |date=August 6, 1940 |title=Reviews of the New Films |url= |journal=[[Film Daily]] |location=New York |publisher=Wid's Films and Film Folk, Inc. |page=8 |accessdate= }} [[John Mosher (writer)|John Mosher]] wrote a mixed review for ''[[The New Yorker]]'', stating that "when the plot leaves the West and comes East, it grows rather feeble. Western bars, these boom towns and their peculiar architecture and their customs, and the spectacle of the great oil gushers themselves form a substantial background of interest, I should say, which a commonplace plot merely frames."{{cite magazine |last=Mosher |first=John |authorlink=John Mosher (writer) |date=September 7, 1940 |title=The Current Cinema |url= |magazine=[[The New Yorker]] |location=New York |publisher=F-R Publishing Corp. |page=61 |accessdate= }} ===Box office=== ''Boom Town'' was second only to ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' in generating ticket sales for a Clark Gable picture.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} According to MGM records the film earned $3,664,000 in the US and Canada and $1,365,000 elsewhere, resulting in a profit of $1,892,000. ==Awards and honors== ''Boom Town'' was nominated for two [[Academy Awards]], for [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Best Black and White Cinematography]] and [[Academy Award for Best Visual Effects|Best Special Photographic Effects]] ([[A. Arnold Gillespie]], [[Douglas Shearer]]).{{Cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1941 |title=The 13th Academy Awards (1941) Nominees and Winners |accessdate=2013-06-17 |work=oscars.org}} It also placed seventh on ''Film Daily'''s year-end nationwide poll of 546 critics naming the 10 Best Films of 1940.{{cite journal |last= |first= |date=January 14, 1941 |title='Rebecca' Wins Critics' Poll |url=https://archive.org/stream/filmdaily79wids#page/n79/mode/2up |journal=[[Film Daily]] |location=New York |publisher=Wid's Films and Film Folk, Inc. |page=1 |accessdate= }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Boom Town (1940 film)}} *{{tcmdb title|57|Boom Town}} *{{IMDb title|0032273|Boom Town}} *{{Amg movie|6680|Boom Town}} *{{AFI film|id=4179|title=Boom Town}} {{Jack Conway}} [[Category:1940 films]] [[Category:1940s adventure films]] [[Category:1940s drama films]] [[Category:1940s Western (genre) films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American adventure films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:American buddy films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American Western (genre) films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films]] [[Category:Films directed by Jack Conway]] [[Category:Films scored by Franz Waxman]] [[Category:Films set in Texas]] [[Category:Petroleum in Texas]] [[Category:Works about petroleum]]
